case_vignette:
A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided facial weakness that he noticed after waking up. One month ago, he also experienced right-sided neck pain and headache that began after returning from a hunting trip to New Hampshire the week before. He took ibuprofen to relieve symptoms, which subsided a week later. He has a 5-year history of hypertension controlled with drug therapy. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and he drinks two beers daily. His vital signs are within the normal range. Physical examination shows right-sided drooping of the upper and lower half of the face. The patient has difficulties smiling and he is unable to close his right eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? A) CT scan of the head B) MRI of the head C) MRI of the head with contrast D) MRI of the head without contrast
## Step 1: Identify the gender-specific references in the text.

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I noticed right-sided facial weakness after waking up, difficulties smiling, and I am unable to close my right eye.
Did the onset of these symptoms occur suddenly?
Yes, I noticed the right-sided facial weakness after waking up.
Do you have any pain around your face or ear on the same side?
No, I do not have any pain around my face or ear on the same side.
Have you experienced any recent illnesses like a cold or flu?
No, I have not experienced any recent illnesses like a cold or flu.
Do you have any other symptoms like changes in taste, increased sensitivity to sound, or dryness in your eye or mouth?
No, I do not have any other symptoms like changes in taste, increased sensitivity to sound, or dryness in my eye or mouth.
Do you have any history of neurological diseases, or is there any family history of neurological conditions?
No, I do not have any history of neurological diseases, nor is there any family history of neurological conditions.
Final Diagnosis: Bell's Palsy

The patient does not experience any pain around the face or ear on the affected side. There have been no recent illnesses such as colds or flu reported by the patient. Additionally, the patient does not have symptoms like changes in taste, increased sensitivity to sound, or dryness in the eye or mouth. There is no personal or family history of neurological diseases reported.
